data.title: EISDIR crash when opening
data.body:
I just attempted to open Atom to work on my project, using `atom .` as usual, only this time I got the debugger with an error stack trace in red. What do I do now?

![screen shot 2015-05-26 at 8 52 04 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/35/7815369/266f7f26-0385-11e5-9f3b-405fa4cae78d.png)

The full stack trace:

`Error: EISDIR: illegal operation on a directory, read
    at Error (native)
    at Object.fs.readSync (fs.js:596:19)
    at Object.fs.readFileSync (fs.js:428:28)
    at Object.fs.readFileSync (ATOM_SHELL_ASAR.js:369:29)
    at File.module.exports.File.readSync (/Users/willkd9/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/pathwatcher/lib/file.js:248:36)
    at TextBuffer.module.exports.TextBuffer.updateCachedDiskContentsSync (/Users/willkd9/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/text-buffer.js:1008:85)
    at TextBuffer.module.exports.TextBuffer.loadSync (/Users/willkd9/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/text-buffer.js:1030:12)
    at Project.module.exports.Project.buildBufferSync (/Users/willkd9/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/project.js:431:14)
    at Project.module.exports.Project.bufferForPathSync (/Users/willkd9/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/project.js:407:61)
    at TokenizedBuffer.module.exports.TokenizedBuffer.deserializeParams (/Users/willkd9/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/tokenized-buffer.js:82:36)`

data.title: Feature Request: Disable autocomplete in comments
data.body:
Comments are generally treated as plaintext. While autocomplete can be helpful in comments at times, at the moment it's really annoying for autocomplete to suggest the word "if" when I want to write "it" in a comment. Occasionally it will suggest the word I want but with different casing. If I hit enter for a new line, autocomplete may select that differently cased word instead of adding a new line as I expect.

Disabling autocomplete in comments seems like a sensible solution to me, but perhaps some discussion is necessary.

![screen shot 2015-05-26 at 10 46 10 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2325487/7815156/b8722d92-0394-11e5-86d9-78b216a6fe16.png)

data.title: Keyboard shortcuts in command palette unreadable after update on Ubuntu 14.04
data.body:
After updating to version 0.201.0, keyboard shortcuts, which are displayed next to the commands when going through the command palette (Ctrl+Shift+P), have a white font on a bright background. 

![command_palette2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4437458/7814052/db0f7a1e-03bf-11e5-947c-57376b8c9001.png)

I think the font colour should be black instead.
I use the webupd8 PPA ppa:webupd8team/atom on Ubuntu 14.04

This issue can be worked around by using a dark UI theme. But with UI themes "One Light" and "Atom Light" the text is pretty much unreadable.

data.title: ctrl + up/down inserts  or 
data.body:
I'm on OSX. Pressing `ctrl` + `up`/`down` inserts a  or  into the document, both show up as a square in the editor.

This is a problem for me personally because. `ctrl` + `left`/`right` is the key combo used to switch between spaces. And my keyboard's arrow buttons are a single square directional button. Which often results in my space switching between browser and Atom to be a combination of both a horizontal and vertical `ctrl` + arrow keypress.

OSX doesn't switch focus away from Atom till after it has finished transitioning to the other space. Because of this I'll often find myself switching away from Atom. Then switching back to find an edited file with an extra square sitting next to my cursor.

Once in awhile I forget to `⌘Z` and I end up saving one of these into a file and have to hunt down the location of the script error it causes.

data.title: Crash related to screen change?
data.body:
Software versions:
- Mac OS X 10.10.3
- Atom 0.201.0
- atom-terminal 0.8.0
- build 0.35.0
- language-lua 0.9.3
- term2 0.9.8

Atom crashed on me twice today, and I think there might be some connection to a change in screen size or multi-monitor setup.

I keep Atom running as I carry my laptop around. When I plugged into an external monitor it was fine, until I dragged the window out larger. Atom crashed before it could render the larger window area. Later, I hid Atom, disconnected the external monitor and put the laptop to sleep. Shortly after waking it up I unhid Atom, and it immediately crashed again.

I can't seem to cause a crash by changing resolution on my laptop screen or playing with the window size and don't have an external monitor handy to play with at the moment. I'll play with that a bit if I get the chance tomorrow.

Both crashes had the same thread and exception type:

```
Crashed Thread:        0  CrRendererMain  Dispatch queue: com.apple.main-thread

Exception Type:        EXC_BAD_INSTRUCTION (SIGILL)
Exception Codes:       0x0000000000000001, 0x0000000000000000
```

They also had remarkably large "Memory Tag 255" segments; 2.0G and 1.9G respectively. I can provide the full crash reports if that helps.

data.title: Don't save `null` repositories
data.body: Putting instances of null in the `@repositories` array can be misleading for packages that want to use `atom.project.getRepositories().length` to know how many repos there actually are instead of how many potential repositories there could be. Right now, I'm filtering the array for non-null values each time I call it.

data.title: Towards unobtrusive notices and notifications
data.body:
This is more of a discussion than a concrete list of actionable items.  Since Atom's launch, I've started to notice more things seeking my attention in an increasingly aggressive manner.  They seem small in isolation, but when you add them up and make them recurring, Atom can begin to nag you.  

Below is the most recent example.  I wanted to take a quick look at some docs, so I run `atom .`  

![screen shot 2015-05-25 at 10 30 25 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25/7800438/3c7af9e6-02ca-11e5-8dbe-b321bf2f7cde.png)

a. **Non-fatal errors are blocking content** - Is this dialog necessary given b.?
b. **Duplicate update notices** - How can Atom minimize these or get rid of them completely? 
c. **The `!` feels unnecessary** - Deprecation and update notices now contain an `!` mark.  It's small, but this changes the tone of the message from informing me, to shouting at me. 
d. **More packages.  more notices** - It seems logical that the longer you are an Atom user, the more package you install, the more notices you are going to get. 
#### Deprecation notices

When you click on the deprecation notice text in the status bar, you are taken to this screen:

![screen shot 2015-05-25 at 10 55 40 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25/7800595/a39f238e-02cc-11e5-8864-90a7e4d5bf04.png)

This screen feels unnecessary to anyone _using_ Atom.  Unless I'm a developer or I'm specifically trying to debug packages, I'm not too concerned with what methods in what packages are deprecated.  I would like the deprecation message to go away so I can get back to work.  How can Atom help me do that?  Could the "Check for updates" step happen automatically?  Could updates be installed during relaunch or during idle time?
#### Package updates

![screen shot 2015-05-25 at 11 07 37 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25/7800708/52e0e5fc-02ce-11e5-86ca-9e0fb9bc78df.png)

There's 1 update available.  When I click the notice in the status bar, I'm taken to this screen that runs an additional check for updates and then lists the packages that have updates.  Does Atom need to run this check again since it knows I have a package that needs an update already? 
#### Some considerations

In the spirit of GitHub Zen, here are a few things to consider:
- Atom should strive to not block content for non-fatal errors. 
- Atom should strive to keep notifications to a minimum.
- Atom should strive to reduce manual administrative overhead (updating packages, atom, etc.). 

:bow:  Thanks for the fantastic work

data.title: Document build flags
data.body:
Refs https://discuss.atom.io/t/install-atom-as-standard-user-on-os-x/17142/2?u=mnquintana

`script/build`'s option flags are currently undocumented for every platform but Linux – this documents it for other platforms.

/cc @atom/feedback

data.title: Add docs about passing a function to a tooltip title
data.body:
This documents the option of passing a function to tooltip's title.

/cc @atom/feedback

data.title: Surrounding multiple words with ` characters is broken
data.body:
I'm not sure which package is responsible so I'm reporting the issue here. Tested with 0.202.0-ec5b807 in `--safe` mode.

When you select multiple words and surround them with " or ' signs everything works perfectly. However, when I try to do the same with `-signs something weird happens (gif is easiest to show). First the words disappear, then I press Space and they reappear - wrapped - but the words are wrong. Note that Cmd-Z removes the `-signs but can not restore the original words.

![atombug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5219415/7797508/51d03dd8-02ed-11e5-8af7-73aebe779bbd.gif)

data.title: Atom may open windows off-screen if resolution/monitors have changed
data.body:
### Reproducible Steps
- Use a laptop with docking station connected with dual monitor setup.
- Move atom editor to second screen.
- Quit atom editor.
- Remove laptop from docking station (or use single screen setup).
- Try open atom editor again.
- Atom editor displayed on second screen, regardless whether second screen exist.
- No easy way to force atom to display on first screen.
### Tested Environment

Atom 0.201.0
Windows 7

data.title: Make chocolatey an official release channel
data.body: Although it is mentioned in README.md, it appears that chocolatey is a third party release channel only. The current version on chocolatey is 0.174.1 and plenty of GitHub releases have been published since then. How about making chocolatey an official release channel so that it gets updated in lock-step with the GitHub releases?

data.title: Save/restore file encoding for opened windows
data.body: For opened Windows, opening Atom should also restore its last encoding status.

data.title: Preferences... should be Settings... or the reverse
data.body: The menu item is Preferences... but the resulting window tab is Settings. They should be consistently named.

data.title: selectLeft reduces selection instead of increasing
data.body:
In this Chrome Devtools session, I call selectLeft() and the selection _decreases_ in size.

The [selectLeft documentation](https://atom.io/docs/api/v0.201.0/Selection#instance-selectLeft) implies that this should not happen:

```
Selects the text one position left of the cursor.
```

Is this a bug in selectLeft?  Is my selection inconsistent?  (it was created by some complex vim-mode code).  Something else?

![screen shot 2015-05-24 at 12 05 48 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1776/7787027/b0832336-01a8-11e5-8aa8-1f488288f910.png)

data.title: Sometimes Reload shortcut doesn't work
data.body:
I had saw this bug for a while on atom. I was a little lazy to report at that time. Sorry !!  I first saw this issue in the 190 releases series at the least.  I reproduced this on 0.194.0.  by clicking `ctrl-alt-r` multiple times. I saw the console errors appear sometimes only. Here is a screenshot   

![mzz5lmm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3112509/7786854/74427b76-0205-11e5-906f-b3021fc3bd23.png)

Info:
- Ubuntu 14.04
- Atom 0.201.0

I think after atom 0.200.0 I stopped see the console errors. Due this I guess

```
Atom no longer displays error notifications for errors where the stack trace 
cannot be accurately attributed to a package or core source file
```

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'scopeName' of undefined
data.body:
Hi, I get this error when I open a very specific html file: **`Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'scopeName' of undefined`** ``` /usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:2090 TypeError: Cannot read property 'scopeName' of undefined at TextEditor.module.exports.TextEditor.usesSoftTabs (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:2090:28) at TextEditor.module.exports.TextEditor.handleTokenization (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:2584:44) at /usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:220:24 at Emitter.module.exports.Emitter.emit (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/event-kit/lib/emitter.js:82:11) at TokenizedBuffer.module.exports.TokenizedBuffer.markTokenizationComplete (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/tokenized-buffer.js:321:22) at TokenizedBuffer.module.exports.TokenizedBuffer.tokenizeNextChunk (/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/tokenized-buffer.js:312:21) at /usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/tokenized-buffer.js:258:26 at /usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/underscore-plus/node_modules/underscore/underscore.js:666:47 ``` I have disabled every community plug-in. I have multiple tabs open with several files, but this error occurs only when I switch to one specific file. I have added the content of the file below, maybe it can help. ``` html {% load staticfiles %} {% load core_date_tags %} {% block extra_css %}{% endblock extra_css %} {% block title %}Mathieu David{% endblock title %}
Mathieu David
Home/ Projects/ About me/ Quick Links
{% block content %} {% endblock content %}
© {{ "2014" | year_range }} | Mathieu David - All rights reserved
{% block extra_js %}{% endblock extra_js %} ``` **EDIT:** I forgot to mention, I am using **version 0.201.0** on Arch Linux
